questions.text: A 38-year-old female with a history of suction & evacuation for molar pregnancy presented with persistent bleeding and nausea On USG, ovaries had theca lutein cysts. Her lab investigations showed rising weekly Serum HCG since the suction evacuation. She was suspected to have Choriocarcinoma. Which of the following can be given as single-drug therapy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Methotrexate

Highyeild:

GTNs are very chemosensitive tumors. In low-risk GTN methotrexate is curative as a single drug agent used at 15–30 mg/day for 5 days. Methotrexate acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase (DHFRase), thus blocking the conversion of dihydrofolic acid (DHFA) to tetrahydrofolic acid (THFA). Etoposide & Vincristine are part of the Bagshawe Regimen given in high-risk GTN and cannot be given as single drug therapy. Infliximab is a chimeral monoclonal antibody that inactivates TNFα. It has proven helpful in refractory rheumatoid arthritis, fistulating Crohn’s disease, ulcerative colitis, psoriasis, and ankylosing spondylitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Etoposide is used to treat different cancers of the blood, lung, and testicles. It is also sometimes used to treat some other kinds of cancer in both men and women. It can be used on its own, or sometimes given together with certain other medicines as part of combination chemotherapy. Option: C. Infliximab is used for the treatment of various inflammatory conditions of the joints (rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis), skin (psoriasis), and bowel (ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease). It reduces inflammation in these conditions by blocking TNF alpha. Option: D. Vincristine also known as leurocristine and marketed under the brand name Oncovin among others, is a chemotherapy medication used to treat a number of types of cancer. This includes acute lymphocytic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia, Hodgkin's disease, neuroblastoma, and small-cell lung cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in the treatment of RA is a purine antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Azathioprine

Highyeild:

Azathioprine is a purine antagonist used in rare cases of RA with systemic manifestation. Azathioprine is added if RA doesn’t respond to first-line DMARDs. Methotrexate is DHFRase inhibitor. It is the first-line drug for the treatment of RA. Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial drug. Its mechanism of action is unclear but is found to reduce IL-1, consequently inhibiting B lymphocytes. 5- fluorouracil is a pyrimidine antagonist. It is used as an anti-cancer agent.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Hydroxychloroquine is used in the treatment of autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus. It slows down the progression of the disease and provides relief from pain, swelling, and redness. Option: C. Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune-system suppressant. It is used to treat cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancies. Types of cancers it is used for include breast cancer, leukemia, lung cancer, lymphoma, gestational trophoblastic disease Option: D. 5- fluorouracil is a cytotoxic chemotherapy medication used to treat cancer. Intravenous injection is used to treat colorectal cancer, oesophageal cancer, stomach cancer, pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, and cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with psoriasis came with severe acute exacerbation. He was put on steroids with Cyclosporine. Which of the following adverse effects is not seen with Cyclosporine?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bone marrow suppression

Highyeild:

Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic, which is its major limitation. It also impairs liver function. Other adverse effects are increased BP, precipitation of diabetes, anorexia, lethargy, hyperkalemia, hyperuricemia, opportunistic infections, hirsutism, gum hyperplasia, tremor, and seizures. However, unlike cytotoxic immunosuppressants, it is rarely also used with toxic effects on bone marrow and the RE system. Humoral immunity remains intact. Side effects of cyclosporine: CV- HTN Hyperlipidemia GI- Nausea, Diarrhea, Hepatotoxicity, Glucose intolerance Renal- Nephrotoxicity, low Mg2+, High K+, Hyperuricemia CNS- Confusion, Hallucination, Convulsion

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic suffered massive STEMI and underwent coronary angioplasty. A drug-coated stent was placed. which of the following statements are INCORRECT about the drug used for coating the stent-

options.label: B
options.text: Concurrent use of Erythromycin can cause drug toxicity

options.label: D
options.text: It acts by inhibiting intranuclear migration of NFAT

questions.correct_answer: D. It acts by inhibiting intranuclear migration of NFAT
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It acts by inhibiting intranuclear migration of NFAT

Highyeild:

The drug used for coating cardiac stents is Sirolimus. It binds to the same immunophilin FKBP as tacrolimus, but the sirolimus-FKBP complex inhibits another kinase called mTOR and does not interact with calcineurin, hence it does not affect NFAT migration. Whereas Cyclosporine and Tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors. Sirolimus is a macrolide antibiotic (like tacrolimus), It can suppress the bone marrow, mainly causing thrombocytopenia. It is extensively metabolized, mainly by CYP3A4. Inhibitors and inducers of CYP3A4 significantly alter its blood level, which needs to be monitored.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It can cause thrombocytopenia is a true statement Option: B. Concurrent use of Erythromycin can cause drug toxicity is a true statement Option: C. It is macrolide antibiotic is a true statement

questions.text: A 55-year-old female scheduled to undergo a liver transplant was put on steroids with a cyclosporine combination before surgery. Which of the following is correct about the mechanism of immunosuppressive action of steroids?

options.label: A
options.text: It binds to helper T cells, prevents their response, and depletes them.

options.label: B
options.text: It blocks the proliferation and differentiation of T and B cells

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibits antigen-stimulated activation and proliferation of helper T cells.

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibit MHC expression and IL-1, IL-2, and IL-6 production.

questions.correct_answer: D. Inhibit MHC expression and IL-1, IL-2, and IL-6 production.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibit MHC expression and IL-1, IL-2, and IL-6 production.

Highyeild:

Glucocorticoids inhibit MHC expression and IL-1, IL-2, and IL-6 production so that helper T-cells are not activated. So, steroids act as anti-inflammatory drugs and hence, they can be used in a lot of autoimmune disorders as immunosuppressants.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for refractory RA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colchicine

Highyeild:

Colchicine is used in acute gouty arthritis. Rest all drugs can be used in the treatment of RA not responding to Methotrexate. Colchicine acts by inhibiting migration of WBCs to the site of inflammation and hence is helpful in acute gouty arthritis whereas Infliximab, Anakinra, and Rituximab are useful when RA doesn’t respond to first-line DMARDs Drug treatment of RA: NSAIDS DMARDS Immunomodulator Methotrexate Cyclosporine Lefhnomide Glucocorticoids TNF- α blocking drug Etanercept Infliximab Adalimumab

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L1 presented with complaints of fever, and pain in skin lesions. She was diagnosed with leprosy before pregnancy and has been on MDT since then. On examination, lesions were red, swollen, and painful to touch. She also complained of the development of new lesions. What adverse effects can be seen in babies if thalidomide is given?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phocomelia

Highyeild:

Phocomelia & multiple defects of internal organs are seen in pregnant females on thalidomide. Phocomelia seen as an adverse effect of Thalidomide refers to the malformed limbs of babies as a result of the adverse effect of the drug on organogenesis. Anticancer days taken during pregnancy can cause fetal death. Drugs and their teratogenic effects: TERATOGENIC DRUGS Drug Effect on Foetus/Offspring ACE Inhibitors Foetal loss Growth retardation Anticancer Drugs Foetal death Hydrocephalus Multiple defects Alcohol Foetal alcohol syndrome Growth retardation Low IQ baby Aspirin Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus Phenytoin Cleft lip/palate Microcephaly Thalidomide Phocomelia Multiple defects Warfarin Eye and hand defects Growth retardation

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient who has been posted for kidney transplantation has been prescribed the drug Basiliximab as a prophylaxis for acute organ transplant rejection. This drug is a monoclonal antibody against:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IL-2 receptor B- Selective IL-2 Receptor Antagonists Basiliximab & Daclizumab Basiliximab is a chimeric antibody composed of 25% murine & 75% human protein. Block IL Daclizumab is humanized antibody composed of 90% human protein Therapeutic Use: Prophylaxis against acute rejection of kidney transplantation > Used in combination with steroids or CSA Basiliximab & Daclizumab are IL-2 receptor antagonists used in prophylaxis for acute organ transplant rejection. Organ transplant is a condition that should be managed with immunosuppression. Rituximab is a CD 20 inhibitor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. IL-1 receptor antagonist: is Anakinra, which is used in Rheumatoid arthritis. Option: D. IL-4 receptor antagonist: is Dipilumab, which is used in Bronchial asthma.

questions.text: A 41-year-old male has been diagnosed with an autoimmune disease. The doctor wants to prescribe him with an immunosuppressant. He wants to give an immunosuppressant that acts through T-helper cells. Which of the following drug can be prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cyclosporine

Highyeild:

Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that enters target cells & binds to cyclophilin, an immunophilin class of protein. Tacrolimus is another calcineurin inhibitor that is also immunosuppressive. The complex then binds to & inactivates calcineurin so that the response of the helper T cell to antigenic stimulation fails. It inhibits antigen-stimulated activation & proliferation of helper T cells as well as expression of IL-2 & other cytokines. Indications for azithromycin in respiratory conditions Antibacterial indications Pharyngitis, tonsillitis (with penicillin allergy) Acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis Community-acquired pneumonia Prevention of Mycobacterium avium complex (and part of treatment regimen) Immunomodulatory indications Cystic fibrosis Diffuse panbronchiolitis Posttransplant bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome Non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Cycloserine is a bacterial cell wall synthesis inhibitor that can be used in tuberculosis as a second-line drug. Option: C. Belimumab inhibits B lymphocyte stimulator & suppresses B cell activation. It is used in the treatment of SLE. Option: D. Azithromycin is used to treat certain bacterial infections such as bronchitis, pneumonia, STD, and nose infection such as sinusitis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis has been prescribed the drug Infliximab. This drug is a monoclonal antibody against:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

TNFα Infliximab, Adalimumab, Certolizumab & Golimumab are monoclonal antibodies against TNF α. TNF alpha is the main cytokine involved in many inflammatory reactions- hence, an effective anti-TNF alpha therapy is mandatory for treatment.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. IL-1 receptor antagonist: is Anakinra, which is used in Rheumatoid arthritis. Option: B. IL-2 receptor antagonist: Basiliximab & Daclizumab, used in the prophylaxis for acute organ transplant rejection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male with bronchial asthma came to the OPD with severe dyspnea. Laboratory investigation showed severe eosinophilia. The doctor wants to prescribe him a monoclonal antibody against IL-5. Which of the following monoclonal antibody can be prescribed to this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mepolizumab IL-5 plays a pivotal role in eosinophilic inflammation & is also involved in eosinophil survival & priming. Anti–IL-5 & anti–IL-5 receptor (IL-5Rα) antibodies inhibit eosinophilic inflammation & airway hyperresponsiveness in patients with mild asthma. Mepolizumab is an anti–IL-5 antibody that has now been FDA-approved for use in highly selected patients with severe asthma. Raslizumab is another antibody that acts by a similar mechanism.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-6 which is used in Rheumatoid arthritis. Option: C. Dupilumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-4 which is used in Eczema. Option: D. Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-2 which is used in the prophylaxis for acute organ transplant rejection.

questions.text: A 49-year-old patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis has been prescribed the drug which antagonizes TNFα. The following drugs could have been prescribed in this case:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Daclizumab Daclizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-2 which is used in the prophylaxis for acute organ transplant rejection (Not in Rheumatoid arthritis).

Highyeild:

Selective IL-2 Receptor Antagonists Basiliximab & Daclizumab (Continue...) Mechanism of action: ➤ They are anti-CD25 antibodies ➤ They bind to the α-chain of the IL-2R (CD25 or TAC subunit) on the activated T-cells ➤ Then, IL-2 binding to IL-2R is prohibited & T- cell activation and proliferation are suppressed

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Etanercept, Option B. Infliximab & Option C. Adalimumab are TNFα inhibitors that are mainly used in refractory rheumatoid arthritis. Certolizumab and etanercept also belong to the same category. It can also be used in Crohn’s disease, ankylosing spondylitis, plaque psoriasis, psoriatic arthritis, and ulcerative colitis. Infusion reaction with fever, urticaria, hypotension & dyspnoea can occur. Risk of serious infections, lymphoma, and other malignancies is present.
